Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the Department of Justice announced a joint action against Hudson City Savings Bank for discriminatory redlining practices that denied residents in majority-Black-and-Hispanic neighborhoods fair access to mortgage loans. The complaint filed by the CFPB and DOJ alleged that Hudson City illegally provided unequal access to credit to neighborhoods in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, and Pennsylvania. The bank located branches and loan officers, selected mortgage brokers, and marketed products to avoid and thereby discourage prospective borrowers in predominantly Black and Hispanic communities. The proposed consent order required Hudson City to pay $25 million in direct loan subsidies to qualified borrowers in the affected communities, $2.25 million in community programs and outreach, and a $5.5 million penalty.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against M&T Bank for deceptively advertising free checking accounts. The CFPB found that M&T lured in consumers with promises of "no strings attached" free checking, without disclosing key eligibility requirements. When consumers failed to meet the requirements, M&T automatically switched them to checking accounts with fees. M&T will provide $2.9 million in refunds to the approximately 59,000 consumers deceived into paying fees and it will pay a $200,000 penalty for the violations.

M&T Bank Corp. agreed to pay $64 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by knowingly originating and underwriting mortgage loans insured by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's Federal Housing Administration that did not meet applicable requirements.

A Delaware-based bank holding company agreed to pay $18.5 million in disgorgement and prejudgment interest to resolve allegations of failing to report the true volume of its loans at least 90 days past due as they substantially increased in number during the financial crisis.

Description: The Labor Department reached an agreement with Wilmington Trust, N.A. requiring it to pay a combined $80 million to 21 employee stock ownership plans (ESOPs) for which it served as trustee and $8 million to the government, and to reimburse plan sponsors of ESOPs for legal costs and expenses advanced in connection with the Department's investigations and litigation.

The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority entered into final settlements with four firms to settle charges relating to the sale of Auction Rate Securities (ARS) that became illiquid when auctions froze in February 2008.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.
